lg.l: They who stay on the road of faultless conduct [shown by] the One
Who subdued the senses' five paths, live long.

div.p: (i-ḷ). mey vāy kaṇ mūkkuc cevi yeṉṉum aim poṟikaḷai vaḻiyākavuṭaiya aintavāviṉaiyum aṟuttāṉatu meyyāṉa voḻukka neṟiyiṉkaṇ vaḻuvātu niṉṟār piṟappiṉṟi yekkālattu moru taṉmaiyarāy vāḻvār, (e-ṟu).

The meaning ... : Those who have stood unerringly upon the road of conduct, which is true, of the One who severed all five of the cravings which have as their paths [to the self] the five sense organs—namely the body, the mouth, the eye[s], the nose, and the ear[s]—live for all time with a single nature, without birth [i.e., without being reborn].

pulaṉkaḷ aintākalāṉ avaṟṟiṉkaṭ celkiṉṟa avāvum aintāyiṟṟu. oḻukkaneṟi aintavittāṉāṟ collappaṭṭamaiyiṉ āṇṭai āṟaṉurupu ceyyuṭkiḻamaikkaṇ vantatu; “kapilaratu pāṭṭu“ eṉpatu pōla. ivai nāṉku pāṭṭāṉum iṟaivaṉai niṉaittalum vāḻttalum avaṉeṟi niṟṟaluñceytār vīṭupeṟuvareṉpatu kūṟappaṭṭatu.

Because the sense-faculties are five, the cravings that travel upon them are also five. Because the road of conduct was taught by the One Who cut off the five, a word for Lord in the genitive case(?) has come [in this verse] in [the sense of showing] authorship (lit. possession) of a literary work, just as [a genitive appears in the phrase] "a song of Kapilar's." Through these four verses, [taken] together, it has been declared that they who contemplate the Lord, live and stay on His path are they who will attain liberation.
i - ḷ:—mey vāy kaṇ mūkkuc cevi eṉṉum aimpoṟikaḷiṉ vaḻiyāka varum ūṟu cuvai oḷi nāṟṟam ōcai eṉṉum aintiṉ kaṇṇum cellum maṉanikaḻcciyai aṭakkiṉāṉatu poyyaṟṟa oḻukka neṟiyilē niṉṟāraṉṟē neṭituvāḻvār.

The meaning ... : They who have stayed (only) upon the path of conduct, free of falsehood, of the One Who subdued the mental occurrences that go upon all five [sensations]—namely touch, taste, sight (lit. light), smell, and hearing—which come as the paths of the five sense-organs—namely the body, mouth, eye[s], nose, and ear[s]—surely live a long [time]!
This [amounts to saying that for them] there is no death.
